metadata.dc:author: Moñux Martínez, A
Toledano Muñoz, A
Galindo Campillo, A N
Bernáldez Millán, R
Gavilán Bouzas, J
metadata.dc:description: Thromboembolism is a risk in major surgical procedures on the head and neck for cancer in predisposed patients. This study was designed to determine if preoperative administration of low-molecular-weight heparin is safe or if it increases the risk of postoperative complications. Preoperative administration of low-molecular-weight heparin was the most important factor in complications such as pharyngo-cutaneous fistula, wound infection, suture dehiscence, or seroma. The second most important factor was surgical technique, and the third factor was neck dissection. Low-molecular-weight heparin did not reduce the risk of thromboembolism. In fact, one patient died suddenly from thromboembolism after surgery.
metadata.dc:title: Profilaxis tromboembólica en pacientes con carcinomas de cabeza y cuello: un estudio riesgo-beneficio.
[Thromboembolic prophylaxis in patients with head and neck carcinomas: a risk-benefit study].
